div.p:
[LibNote]Nov [unclear]26[/unclear][/LibNote] 1842
[LibNote]65[/LibNote]
Here is the irreverend
scrap that your reverend
daughter has handed me with
an air, to write to you upon
my dearest mother
I have no objection in life to
dirty notes but I do not want
dirty or clean here - Keep
them for me - if they belong to me
but I thought we had settled
that you were [underline]not[/underline] to pay me my
Quarter Div[superscript]d[/superscript] due July 1[superscript]st[/superscript] if that
is what you are talking of
I see before me this
instant an entry in my book
shewing that you paid me
Aug[superscript]t[/superscript]. 10[superscript]h[/superscript]. that Quarter -} 85 .. 7 . 8
by [deletion]draft[/deletion] [insertion][unclear]codicdal[/unclear][/insertion] [insertion][unclear]lodged on Balls -}
And that I paid you in cash - 21.. 12.. 4
making up my House acct 107 . 0 . 0
quarter due Sep[superscript]r[/superscript] 1[superscript]st[/superscript] -
So what you are now talking
of my dear Madam about notes due
to me dirty or clean I do not know
- But shall be very glad to have
any due & honestly mine - only you keep
them till we meet on the 21[superscript]st[/superscript]. Prox [deletion][/deletion]
M[superscript]r[/superscript]. Ralstones is a most touch
ing manly letter - I had written
to him before breakfast this morn[superscript]g[/superscript]
and found his letter on your
cover when I came down - I shall send it as
it was truly written - I am afraid you did not
read M[superscript]rs[/superscript] Moores [/unclear] characteristic & really ex letter I
return it therefore - I will
answer what you are pleased
to call [underline]the politest note I ever
received[/underline] - polite enough I
grant - but the polit[underline]est![/underline] Oh
- exaggeration -
I shall refer him to M[superscript]rs[/superscript] Hall [unclear][/unclear]
for my part I can have no objection
to republishing him, what has been
published & the [underline]truths[/underline] which
every one knows! - What is modesty
those who have it may answer
& throw the first stone.
Thank you my dear for your
history of Dole's delights - and Marys
which delighted your affectionately
very much
ME
The carriage is coming at eleven
(& it is now I do not know how much
passed [deletion]eleven[/deletion] ten) to carry us to
Black Castle by appointment
Morning vis - paid a very agree
able Vis yester morn & rather evening
after luncheon bagged, to Lady Harriet [unclear]Knowles[/unclear]
& knew that Rev[superscript]d[/superscript] Frank old boy is Frank
My cidevant Creditor - not a word about
vile trash - quite full of wit and classics
& regrets that he [unclear][/unclear]
& [unclear][/unclear] that he [unclear]never[/unclear]
a regular classical Ed[superscript]n[/superscript].
and the more enter
taining he is for being
quite inconsistent in
all he says & does -
The most [unclear]decousee[/unclear]
mind & conversation
you can conceive
Mica of ability -
glittering thin brittle
lamina or [unclear]no[/unclear]
thats all - told many
things which if ascertained
to be facts w[superscript]d[/superscript] be interesting
and curious - But at every
[unclear]close[/unclear] or pause M[superscript]r[/superscript]. Fowler
rev[superscript]d[/superscript] husband of Lady
Harriet, asked
Where did you hear that
Frank - Where did you speak
up [underline]that[/underline] [unclear]Saunderson[/unclear]
For instance he
told of a poisonous acre
near [unclear]athboy[/unclear] on which cattle
infallibly lose their hoofs &
their horns & on which the potatoes that grow are reported to
be poisonous
